title: Dusk Till Dawn.
description:
by xxitisbluexx

Allí, a lomos de un caballo moribundo, Arya Stark se presentó frente a él como las respuestas a sus plegarias para encontrar el camino a seguir.

«A veces dos caminos diferentes llevan al mismo castillo.»

summary:
Needle was Robb and Bran and Rickon, her mother and her father, even Sansa.
Needle was Winterfell's grey walls, and the laughter...
body:
Needle was Robb and Bran and Rickon, her mother and her father, even Sansa.

Needle was Winterfell’s grey walls, and the laughter of its people. Needle was the summer snows, Old Nan’s stories, the heart tree with its red leaves and scary face, the warm earthy smell of the glass gardens, the sound of the north wind rattling the shutters of her room.

Needle was Jon Snow’s smile. He used to mess my hair and call me “little sister,” she remembered, and suddenly there were tears in her eyes.

•

[Arya, A Feast For Crows]

summary: To go South - chapter 48 - Playing cyvasse
title: To go South - chapter 48 - Playing cyvasse
body:
So, here is another chapter on the battle at Winterfell. Bran’s PoV. We do not catch up yet to the end of the Da€nerys’ chapter, but we’ll reach that at the end of the next chapter. Also on AO3.

Bran could hear their voices all the time now. It made it difficult to concentrate on what people said. The voices of the children drowned everything out. Their voices were the pulse of the earth in autumn, a slight breeze in summer, the steady dropping of a spring rain. They were insistent, urging him. He concentrated on the plan to trap the White Walkers. He dared not think beyond that. They did not understand that he would think about his family, not when they were so close to the thin veil that separated them from the access to their magic. He could hide his thoughts behind his worry for his family. In a way it was an advantage that they were all in danger.

He didn’t need to touch the weirwood any longer, and it would be a risk anyway. Bran doubted he could hide anything from them if he opened his thoughts again to the weirwood. He had not even dared to take the arrows from the tree. The children had reached out and hid Bran and Theon from the White Walkers. The enemy would not sense them, not as long as there was a feast of living souls they could expect to drain as soon as they had won the castle.

Bran let his mind wander, seeing, but not acting. The time for action would come later, for now the pieces were all set. He wondered if his siblings would think him cold. A part of him knew that they would not appreciate to be moved like pieces on a cyvasse board, but that was as far as his understanding went. He knew that they probably would be angry with him, but he did not feel it, nor did he dread their hurt.

Brienne and Jaime were fighting in a steady and constant rhythm, as if they were one person, sensing the other’s weakness, raising their swords to help the other.

Arya was a small whirlwind. Needle was everywhere, and although Gendry and her did not complement each other as well as Brienne and Jaime, they easily held their own. Bran saw the Unsullied edging closer to Gendry, the fighting was thick, but this was up to Arya.

Theon’s touch brought him back into his own body.

“Bran,” he said. “I thought about this. I don’t claim to understand everything, but I do think there is a flaw in your argument. You say it is all about balance, but if we can restore balance by destroying the White Walkers with wildfire and then killing the dragons, why can’t we do it, the other way round? Kill the dragons and then the fire magic is gone, and then White Walkers will die as well.”

Bran shook his head. We could have done that, if Daenerys had let us. But she would not give up her dragons. He would have to come up with something that would appease Theon and the voices in his head.

“If the White Walkers are killed first, the Children regain their strength and only then the arrows will be strong enough to kill the dragons. It is crucial that the scales first tip in favour of fire. It is the ice magic that channels the strength away from the Children.”

The voices in his head were satisfied. Bran could feel their pressure in his head lessen for a moment, and he heard something that felt like the far away echo of a chuckle. Quickly, he distracted himself from the sound. It would be no good if they realised that he knew they were manipulating him.

“I’ll tell you when to act. I just have to check on Jon.”

Before he concentrated on the battle again, he saw worry cast a shadow on Theon’s face. He knew he probably looked creepy when he delved into his visions, but that was not to be helped.

Bran checked on Rhaegal. It was interesting how the wall of earth magic he and Jon had built around his mind had changed the dragon. His contained fire was less dangerous, more focussed than Drogon’s, but it was still fire. Fire made flesh. Bran briefly touched Jon’s mind reassuringly. He wondered if he should have told his cousin to not grow too attached to the beast.

Sansa was leading the everybody down into the crypts. Bran could feel the tiny, tiny fleck of a being close to her heart, and he brushed his nephew ever so lightly. Olyvar Frey was at Sansa’s side, his eyes restive and Ghost flanked her on the other side. Bran could feel that Sansa was frightened, but he was sure nobody would realise that. She calmly managed the constant stream of people.

It was time now. The enemy was closing in, claiming the castle. Bran knew that there was no chance he could close of the crypts with everybody on the inside.

Arya and Gendry were at the rearguard. They might be cut off.

He knew he should be sad about this, but he had no tears. Maybe I will have tears later, when this is all over. That was a dangerous thought, he could feel the resentment and lack of understanding from the Children about his yearning for tears. He stamped on his worry for Arya. He had seen that she had a decent chance of survival after all.

Sansa led the living deeper and deeper into the tunnels. Brienne and Jaime were at the end of the column. Tyrion chose this moment to finally unburden his conscience. He had been in the middle of the column, but now he ran back and looked for his brother, his stride was unsteady. He must have drunk many tankards to be that affected.

“Jaime,” he called, “Jaime.”

His brother barely managed to save him from being killed by a White Walker when he buried his Valyrian sword in the White Walker mere moments before he touched Tyrion.

“What are you doing here?”

Bran waited. He should call the Kings of Winter now and he could feel the Children pressuring him. He stood his ground.

I don’t want them to die. I don’t want anyone to die. Go, now, leave this room, he tried to tell them.

“Sansa, I think she is in danger.” Tyrion blurted out. There were tears in his eyes. “I should have told you earlier. I think Daenerys might have bribed someone to kill her.”

Jaime pushed his brother. “Get yourself to safety. And don’t you worry. Olyvar is with Sansa.”

“But he must be the one she bribed. She said something about ‘Once a traitor always a traitor’.”

Brienne barked a laugh. “As if Olyvar would betray the woman who saved him. Believe me, Sansa is safe with him. He told us all about it and he played along.”

Bran pressed a hand to his head. The pressure was getting worse.

Tyrion looked at Brienne, understanding dawning on him. “You knew?”

“I am the Commander of the Queensguard, of course I knew.”

Jaime pushed his brother again. “Now, please, look after yourself. I have to fight.”

Wights were coming at them, but Tyrion did not see them. Maybe he was too drunk.

“Jaime,” Tyrion wailed. “I failed you. You protected King’s Landing, but I did not manage to do what you did. King’s Landing is gone and so is Cersei.”

Brienne cursed. “Why did you choose this moment to burst out with that!”

She was swinging her sword right and left, but her easy rhythm was gone. Jaime skipped a beat and Brienne barely managed to keep him from getting butchered.

“I suspected as much, Tyrion, and now, by all the Gods, get your arse out of here.”

Bran would have to risk it. Tyrion had distracted him, the chance for him running back had not been that high, and he had lost contact to Arya. He hoped that she was deeper in the crypts. He called upon the Kings of Winter like he had already done once before. He was in awe that it was so much easier now, he felt the strength of Winterfell’s magic deep in his bones. The Children were satisfied.

The statues moved and protected the crypts to where the living had fled.

Bran opened his eyes and looked at the sky that was tinged with a silver lining that forebode the dawn. A time of change, this was the right moment, between night and day, time for decisions.

“They’ll spring the trap now,” he told Theon.

He concentrated on the plan to trap the White Walkers. He dared not think beyond that. They did not understand that he would think about his family, not when they were so close to the thin veil that separated them from the access to their magic. He could hide his thoughts behind his worry for his family. In a way it was an advantage that they were all in danger.

His contained fire was less dangerous, more focussed than Drogon’s, but it was still fire. Fire made flesh. Bran briefly touched Jon’s mind reassuringly. He wondered if he should have told his cousin to not grow too attached to the beast.

Sansa was leading the everybody down into the crypts. Bran could feel the tiny, tiny fleck of a being close to her heart, and he brushed his nephew ever so lightly. Olyvar Frey was at Sansa’s side, his eyes restive and Ghost flanked her on the other side. Bran could feel that Sansa was frightened, but he was sure nobody would realise that. She calmly managed the constant stream of people.

It was time now. The enemy was closing in, claiming the castle. Bran knew that there was no chance he could close of the crypts with everybody on the inside.

Arya and Gendry were at the rearguard. They might be cut off.

He knew he should be sad about this, but he had no tears. Maybe I will have tears later, when this is all over. That was a dangerous thought, he could feel the resentment and lack of understanding from the Children about his yearning for tears. He stamped on his worry for Arya. He had seen that she had a decent chance of survival after all.

Sansa led the living deeper and deeper into the tunnels. Brienne and Jaime were at the end of the column. Tyrion chose this moment to finally unburden his conscience. He had been in the middle of the column, but now he ran back and looked for his brother, his stride was unsteady. He must have drunk many tankards to be that affected.

“Jaime,” he called, “Jaime.”

His brother barely managed to save him from being killed by a White Walker when he buried his Valyrian sword in the White Walker mere moments before he touched Tyrion.

“What are you doing here?”

Bran waited. He should call the Kings of Winter now and he could feel the Children pressuring him. He stood his ground.

I don’t want them to die. I don’t want anyone to die. Go, now, leave this room, he tried to tell them.

“Sansa, I think she is in danger.” Tyrion blurted out. There were tears in his eyes. “I should have told you earlier. I think Daenerys might have bribed someone to kill her.”

Jaime pushed his brother. “Get yourself to safety. And don’t you worry. Olyvar is with Sansa.”

“But he must be the one she bribed. She said something about ‘Once a traitor always a traitor’.”

Brienne barked a laugh. “As if Olyvar would betray the woman who saved him. Believe me, Sansa is safe with him. He told us all about it and he played along.”

Bran pressed a hand to his head. The pressure was getting worse.

Tyrion looked at Brienne, understanding dawning on him. “You knew?”

“I am the Commander of the Queensguard, of course I knew.”

Jaime pushed his brother again. “Now, please, look after yourself. I have to fight.”

Wights were coming at them, but Tyrion did not see them. Maybe he was too drunk.

“Jaime,” Tyrion wailed. “I failed you. You protected King’s Landing, but I did not manage to do what you did. King’s Landing is gone and so is Cersei.”

Brienne cursed. “Why did you choose this moment to burst out with that!”

She was swinging her sword right and left, but her easy rhythm was gone. Jaime skipped a beat and Brienne barely managed to keep him from getting butchered.

“I suspected as much, Tyrion, and now, by all the Gods, get your arse out of here.”

Bran would have to risk it. Tyrion had distracted him, the chance for him running back had not been that high, and he had lost contact to Arya. He hoped that she was deeper in the crypts. He called upon the Kings of Winter like he had already done once before. He was in awe that it was so much easier now, he felt the strength of Winterfell’s magic deep in his bones. The Children were satisfied.

The statues moved and protected the crypts to where the living had fled.

Bran opened his eyes and looked at the sky that was tinged with a silver lining that forebode the dawn. A time of change, this was the right moment, between night and day, time for decisions.

“They’ll spring the trap now,” he told Theon.

trail.content_raw:
So, here is another chapter on the battle at Winterfell. Bran’s PoV. We do not catch up yet to the end of the Da€nerys’ chapter, but we’ll reach that at the end of the next chapter. Also on AO3.

Bran could hear their voices all the time now. It made it difficult to concentrate on what people said. The voices of the children drowned everything out. Their voices were the pulse of the earth in autumn, a slight breeze in summer, the steady dropping of a spring rain. They were insistent, urging him. He concentrated on the plan to trap the White Walkers. He dared not think beyond that. They did not understand that he would think about his family, not when they were so close to the thin veil that separated them from the access to their magic. He could hide his thoughts behind his worry for his family. In a way it was an advantage that they were all in danger.

[[MORE]]

He didn’t need to touch the weirwood any longer, and it would be a risk anyway. Bran doubted he could hide anything from them if he opened his thoughts again to the weirwood. He had not even dared to take the arrows from the tree. The children had reached out and hid Bran and Theon from the White Walkers. The enemy would not sense them, not as long as there was a feast of living souls they could expect to drain as soon as they had won the castle.

Bran let his mind wander, seeing, but not acting. The time for action would come later, for now the pieces were all set. He wondered if his siblings would think him cold. A part of him knew that they would not appreciate to be moved like pieces on a cyvasse board, but that was as far as his understanding went. He knew that they probably would be angry with him, but he did not feel it, nor did he dread their hurt.

Brienne and Jaime were fighting in a steady and constant rhythm, as if they were one person, sensing the other’s weakness, raising their swords to help the other.

Arya was a small whirlwind. Needle was everywhere, and although Gendry and her did not complement each other as well as Brienne and Jaime, they easily held their own. Bran saw the Unsullied edging closer to Gendry, the fighting was thick, but this was up to Arya.

Theon’s touch brought him back into his own body.

“Bran,” he said. “I thought about this. I don’t claim to understand everything, but I do think there is a flaw in your argument. You say it is all about balance, but if we can restore balance by destroying the White Walkers with wildfire and then killing the dragons, why can’t we do it, the other way round? Kill the dragons and then the fire magic is gone, and then White Walkers will die as well.”

Bran shook his head. We could have done that, if Daenerys had let us. But she would not give up her dragons. He would have to come up with something that would appease Theon and the voices in his head.

“If the White Walkers are killed first, the Children regain their strength and only then the arrows will be strong enough to kill the dragons. It is crucial that the scales first tip in favour of fire. It is the ice magic that channels the strength away from the Children.”

The voices in his head were satisfied. Bran could feel their pressure in his head lessen for a moment, and he heard something that felt like the far away echo of a chuckle. Quickly, he distracted himself from the sound. It would be no good if they realised that he knew they were manipulating him.

“I’ll tell you when to act. I just have to check on Jon.”

Before he concentrated on the battle again, he saw worry cast a shadow on Theon’s face. He knew he probably looked creepy when he delved into his visions, but that was not to be helped.

Bran checked on Rhaegal. It was interesting how the wall of earth magic he and Jon had built around his mind had changed the dragon. His contained fire was less dangerous, more focussed than Drogon’s, but it was still fire. Fire made flesh. Bran briefly touched Jon’s mind reassuringly. He wondered if he should have told his cousin to not grow too attached to the beast.

Sansa was leading the everybody down into the crypts. Bran could feel the tiny, tiny fleck of a being close to her heart, and he brushed his nephew ever so lightly. Olyvar Frey was at Sansa’s side, his eyes restive and Ghost flanked her on the other side. Bran could feel that Sansa was frightened, but he was sure nobody would realise that. She calmly managed the constant stream of people.

It was time now. The enemy was closing in, claiming the castle. Bran knew that there was no chance he could close of the crypts with everybody on the inside.

Arya and Gendry were at the rearguard. They might be cut off.

He knew he should be sad about this, but he had no tears. Maybe I will have tears later, when this is all over. That was a dangerous thought, he could feel the resentment and lack of understanding from the Children about his yearning for tears. He stamped on his worry for Arya. He had seen that she had a decent chance of survival after all.

Sansa led the living deeper and deeper into the tunnels. Brienne and Jaime were at the end of the column. Tyrion chose this moment to finally unburden his conscience. He had been in the middle of the column, but now he ran back and looked for his brother, his stride was unsteady. He must have drunk many tankards to be that affected.

“Jaime,” he called, “Jaime.”

His brother barely managed to save him from being killed by a White Walker when he buried his Valyrian sword in the White Walker mere moments before he touched Tyrion.

“What are you doing here?”

Bran waited. He should call the Kings of Winter now and he could feel the Children pressuring him. He stood his ground.

I don’t want them to die. I don’t want anyone to die. Go, now, leave this room, he tried to tell them.

“Sansa, I think she is in danger.” Tyrion blurted out. There were tears in his eyes. “I should have told you earlier. I think Daenerys might have bribed someone to kill her.”

Jaime pushed his brother. “Get yourself to safety. And don’t you worry. Olyvar is with Sansa.”

“But he must be the one she bribed. She said something about ‘Once a traitor always a traitor’.”

Brienne barked a laugh. “As if Olyvar would betray the woman who saved him. Believe me, Sansa is safe with him. He told us all about it and he played along.”

Bran pressed a hand to his head. The pressure was getting worse.

Tyrion looked at Brienne, understanding dawning on him. “You knew?”

“I am the Commander of the Queensguard, of course I knew.”

Jaime pushed his brother again. “Now, please, look after yourself. I have to fight.”

Wights were coming at them, but Tyrion did not see them. Maybe he was too drunk.

“Jaime,” Tyrion wailed. “I failed you. You protected King’s Landing, but I did not manage to do what you did. King’s Landing is gone and so is Cersei.”

Brienne cursed. “Why did you choose this moment to burst out with that!”

She was swinging her sword right and left, but her easy rhythm was gone. Jaime skipped a beat and Brienne barely managed to keep him from getting butchered.

“I suspected as much, Tyrion, and now, by all the Gods, get your arse out of here.”

Bran would have to risk it. Tyrion had distracted him, the chance for him running back had not been that high, and he had lost contact to Arya. He hoped that she was deeper in the crypts. He called upon the Kings of Winter like he had already done once before. He was in awe that it was so much easier now, he felt the strength of Winterfell’s magic deep in his bones. The Children were satisfied.

The statues moved and protected the crypts to where the living had fled.

Bran opened his eyes and looked at the sky that was tinged with a silver lining that forebode the dawn. A time of change, this was the right moment, between night and day, time for decisions.

“They’ll spring the trap now,” he told Theon.

blog.name: aqueenofmarble
blog.title: Do I Dare Disturb the Universe?

summary: Hbo brasil just posted a little arya/gendry edit on twitter with the title: a meeting we are looking forward to and we cannot...
body:
Hbo brasil just posted a little arya/gendry edit on twitter with the title: a meeting we are looking forward to and we cannot wait to see. 10 days left.

Looool istg everyone’s shipping gendrya so hard!
